inscribed:
Inscribed in blue watercolor, lower right below signature: Rockland, Me.
Inscribed in graphite, on  verso upper left: Trawler and Telegraph Pole
signed: Signed in blue watercolor, lower right: Edward Hopper

texts.textentryhtml: Hopper produced more than thirty watercolors during the summer of 1926 while in Rockland, Maine, known for its shipbuilding and lime quarries. In these this example, he foregrounds a telegraph pole, and massive beam trawlers along the waterfront. These pictorial devices interrupt our view into the composition, enhancing a sense of physical and psychological isolation. As in many of Hopper’s urban landscapes, the absence of figures underscores the feeling of mystery and silence communicated by the spare, abstracted forms.
texts.remarks: Painting on Paper: American Watercolors at Princeton

texts.textentryhtml: Frank K. M. Rehn Gallery, New York, 1926; Clifton R. Hall, Princeton, New Jersey.;
